active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group debate, argue whether full redundancy (e.g., mirrored data centers) is always necessary for all organizations or if risk-based approaches suffice, using real-world examples from healthcare (critical availability) vs. e-commerce (cost-sensitive scalability). Reference ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.8.14 and CIA triad.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Base on common misconceptions (e.g., 'Redundancy guarantees 100% uptime' as distractor).
Use partial truths (e.g., 'Only hardware redundancy needed' ignoring software/site).
Include extremes (e.g., 'No redundancy ever needed'), similar terms (e.g., confuse failover with backup), or unrelated concepts (e.g., mix with Confidentiality).
Ensure 3 distractors per MCQ; one closest to correct for higher difficulty.

Core content: ISO A.8.14 requires IPFs (ICT infrastructure) with redundancy to meet availability needs, preventing single points of failure via duplication (e.g., RAID, failover clusters, geo-redundant DCs; active-active/passive). Supports CIA Availability and business continuity/DRP. Steps: assess RTO/RPO, design/implement/test failover. Misconceptions: !=100% uptime; not just hardware. Prior knowledge: CIA triad (Availability), risk assessment, IT basics (servers, networks).
